comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content:
I'm pretty sure they mean "Serbian."  The date says 7/28/14 -- if correct, this was taken on the day that Austria-Hungary invaded Serbia, i.e. the first day of World War I.

A terrible number of the men in these photos died in battle over the next four years.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
Serbia was called Servia then.

Other Bain/LOC photos of Servian/Serbian troops:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5739978341/in/photostream]
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5740529364/in/photostream/]

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: Yes, it was common usage then -- like "Bombay" vs. "Mumbai," I guess. I didn't trust Bain not to misspell, but the NYT uses the same name: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Nytimes06-29-1914.jpg

comment.author: 92284803@N00
comment._content: The Bombay/Mumbai situation is more complicated than that.
